instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3302: What is 820-3302? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2012 iMac no power
threads.message:
This iMac was powering on at first but experiencing the fan running at full speed, even when shut off. I would unplug the power cable, then plug back in without turning the iMac back on and the fan would spin at full speed again. The client took the iMac home over the weekend, but it powered off on her, and now there is no power.
Here is what I found. Power supply is good (had known good power supply I swapped). 

Back to the motherboard:
I used a thermal camera and found <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> appeared to be shorting, so I removed this chip and still had shorts on the following pins:
4,3,21,20,48,46,42,32.
Because where these appear to go, <SIGNAL>REG_CPUCORE_VSEN</SIGNAL> being one, does this mean the CPU is fried?
Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2012 iMac no power
threads.message: Update, I did not realize the CPU was removable but when I took the cpu out, the short is gone, but I tried sticking in another LGA1155 intel processor I had in stock, and the short returned with this one too. I am thinking the processor is just completing the circuit, but I have no idea where to go from here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2012 iMac no power
threads.message:
Ivy Bridge CPU has very los resistance on its core; usually 1-3 ohm, depending of type (i7-i3).

Did you remove CMOS coil?
Any LED comes on?
<TRANSISTOR>Q7870</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> are the first suspects.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2012 iMac no power
threads.message:
No shorts on <TRANSISTOR>Q7870</TRANSISTOR> or <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>.
Only 1 LED light comes on (the one at the bottom).
I did remove the CMOS battery but not sure which one is the COIL?
I do have a short on <TRANSISTOR>Q8961</TRANSISTOR> pins 7 and 8. When I search this in the schematic though, it finds nothing. I am seeing this using the boardview.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2012 iMac no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8000</CHIP> keeps lighting up when I inject voltage in to <CAPACITOR>C8962</CAPACITOR> pin 1. I keep finding shorts that correspond to <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>.
<RESISTOR>R8910</RESISTOR> pin 2 also has a short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2012 iMac no power
threads.message:
Sorry about "coil"; read "cell" instead.

If LED1 stays on, <TRANSISTOR>Q7870</TRANSISTOR> is good.
Nobody said to check for short on it, nor at <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR>.
These MOSFETs suffer by leakage usually.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>12V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>.

"I do have a short on <TRANSISTOR>Q8961</TRANSISTOR> pins 7 and 8."
Maybe, but GPU core has also low resistance to ground; compare with similar board.
